ygData.subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Re: The "new media types are evil" meme
ygData.msgSnippet: Hola, ... I dare say, that is your opinion, of course. However, there s something slightly bigger at stake here. IMHO, of course. ... The semantics of *what*

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

Hola,

"Mike Kelly" <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
> No, not in this particular case.

I dare say, that is your opinion, of course. However, there's something
slightly bigger at stake here. IMHO, of course.

> There's nothing inherently wrong about statements like "the semantics
> of POST requests vary for different resources".

The semantics of *what* about POST, exactly? This is where I see a subtle
rift in the space-time continuum that threatens to divide RESTafarians
everywhere. There's choices in resources as gateways into larger HATEOS
frameworks or as those subtler resources themselves, resources as APIs
themselves, and so on, all along the scale of correctness from bad to good;
the only semantics that REST cares about is "process this". Whatever you
place on top is your business, and exist in the ontology layer (with vocab
names / schemas / RDF(x) / whatever.

Again; it is *important* to point out that *REST* has no more semantics on
a resource than "process this". Get this wrong, and you start blaming REST
for problems that exists elsewhere.

> The key is that those
> varying semantics are _not visible_ on the network and are derived
> only from the shared understanding between client and server. That's
> not a violation of REST constraints or the HTTP spec, it's a small
> clarification.

You think it is small. Some of us think it is subtle - for sure - but
rather important. As soon as you think REST (or your favourite REST
implementation, like HTTP) carries semantics outside of the generic methods
and the generic response codes, you will blame it for all of your own
failings, and you might just miss out on the magic of REST in the process.

Again, all those semantics you talk about are supposed to be in the
content-type of the request and the content negotiation with given
resources. This is one area in which cool URIs are misleading.

> I definitely agree though, there are some REST constraints and
> concepts that are misused. This seems to happen frequently with terms
> like 'visibility' and 'self-descriptive' :)

Well, I personally think that most people who understand REST, do not
understand REST, most probably myself included. It's a nice set of
constraints and methods that, when combined, gives awesome benefits, but
trying to explain the whole cake by pointing out its ingrediants will never
convince anyone.

The terms you point to are, in fact, quite often used more correct when
spoken, but not so much when heard, but that's just a side effect of having
poorly separated the REST fundamentals from the ontology and the
application specific noise. In terms of REST, visibility and portions being
self-descriptive is spot on - but in a strict REST sense, not the ontology
sense.

In other words, I can claim that POST on a given resource is
self-descriptive, as in "process this", but when other people hear me say
it, it comes across as "the ontology payload describes the resource and its
links", which is a different beast all-together.

Anyway, that was a long-winded way of agree with you on that sentiment. :)

Regards,

Alex

--0015174be5a20a473004b59dc119
Content-Type: text/html; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
